en.gameover: ALL DONE! Tap here when you're ready to end the game.
en.intro1_1: Hello Captain! You made it just in time!
en.intro1_2: The <color=#FCC630>Professor</color> is about to share his research with us!
en.intro1_2_speak: The Professor is about to share his research with us!
en.intro1_4_speak: Today we'll learn about Plate Tectonics!
en.intro1_5: The Earth’s outer shell is where we live and it’s broken up into pieces called <color=#FCC630>Tectonic Plates!</color>
en.intro1_5_speak: The Earth’s outer shell is where we live and it’s broken up into pieces called Tectonic Plates!
en.intro2_1: Ever look at a map and notice how some continents fit <color=#FCC630>perfectly like puzzle pieces?</color>
en.intro2_1_speak: Ever look at a map and notice how some continents fit perfectly like puzzle pieces?
en.intro2_2: Scientists believe that millions of years ago, our continents were all once part of a giant continent called <color=#FCC630>Pangaea.</color>
en.intro2_2_speak: Scientists believe that millions of years ago, our continents were all once part of a giant continent called Pangaea.
en.intro2_3: Different chunks of land broke off the <color=#FCC630>Pangaea</color> and <color=#FCC630>very slowly</color> drifted apart.
en.intro2_3_speak: Different chunks of land broke off the Pangaea and very slowly drifted apart.
en.intro2_4: These chunks became the continents we now live in and this is how the <color=#FCC630>Earth</color> looks today!
en.intro2_4_speak: These chunks became the continents we now live in and this is how the Earth looks today!
en.intro2_5: We'll find out how this happened and more by studying <color=#FCC630>Plate Tectonics!</color>
en.intro2_5_speak: We'll find out how this happened and more by studying Plate Tectonics!
en.intro2_6: We'll learn about <color=#FCC630>Plates, The Ring of Fire, Mountain Ranges, Volcanoes, Trenches, Earthquakes</color> and <color=#FCC630>more!</color>
en.intro2_6_speak: We'll learn about Plates, The Ring of Fire, Mountain Ranges, Volcanoes, Trenches, Earthquakes and more!
en.intro2_7: HA-HA! I've come to take your <color=#FCC630>Plate Tectonics</color> research!
en.intro2_7_speak: HA-HA! I've come to take your Plate Tectonics research!
en.intro2_8_speak: Oh no! It's the Evil Prospector!
en.intro2_9: <color=#FCC630>Plate Tectonics</color> knowledge will help me locate Earth's valuable resources and I'll become filthy rich! HA-HA!
en.intro2_9_speak: Plate Tectonics knowledge will help me locate Earth's valuable resources and I'll become filthy rich! HA-HA!
en.intro2_10: Help <color=#FCC630>Super Study Buddies</color>! You're our only hope.
en.intro2_10_speak: Help Super Study Buddies! You're our only hope.
en.mountain_ranges_trivia: Found in bunches, usually near the middle or edges of a continent.
en.volcanoes_trivia: A volcano is an opening in the crust that releases hot lava, ash and debris.
en.trenches_trivia: Found along ocean floors where rock in Earth's crust sinks back down into the mantle.
en.ring_of_fire_trivia: The pacific ring of fire has more exploding volcanoes and great earthquakes than any other place on earth!
en.earthquakes_trivia: Usually happens along faults, the place where two or more plates meet.
en.area1_instructions1: Please help me recover my research from the evil prospector's bad bots!
en.area1_instructions2: Thank you so much! But the prospector won't give up that easily. Please help my friends!
en.lesson1_instructions1: The Earth has an outer shell like an egg! How do you crack an egg?
en.lesson1_instructions2: Remove all of the tectonic plates so we can take a look inside!
en.lesson1_text1: The pieces that make up the outer shell are called <color=ffffff>Tectonic Plates!</color>
en.lesson1_text1_speak: The pieces that make up the outer shell are called Tectonic Plates!
en.lesson1_text2: The cracks between the plates are called <color=ffffff>faults!</color>
en.lesson1_text2_speak: The cracks between the plates are called faults!
en.lesson1_text3: The Earth's <color=ffffff>inner and outer cores</color> are extremely hot!
en.lesson1_text3_speak: The Earth's inner and outer cores are extremely hot!
en.lesson1_text4: The <color=ffffff>mantle</color> is hot, soft and solid rock.
en.lesson1_text4_speak: The mantle is hot, soft and solid rock.
en.lesson1_text5: The <color=ffffff>crust</color> contains rock, soil and sediment. This is where you live!
en.lesson1_text5_speak: The crust contains rock, soil and sediment. This is where you live!
en.lesson1_text6: The <color=ffffff>lithosphere</color> is made up of the upper mantle and the crust.
en.lesson1_text6_speak: The lithosphere is made up of the upper mantle and the crust.
en.lesson1_text7: The <color=ffffff>lithosphere</color> is where the moving <color=ffffff>tectonic plates</color> are!
en.lesson1_text7_speak: The lithosphere is where the moving tectonic plates are!
en.lesson2_instruction1: Imagine this burner is the Earth's Core and the mantle is the boiling soup.
en.lesson2_instruction2: Can't have soup with just water so let's add a few ingredients.
en.lesson2_instruction4: The heat makes the soup behave this way. Similar to what the core does to the mantle.
en.lesson2_instruction5: And as the mantle moves, it takes the plates for a ride.
en.lesson2_instruction6_speak: This movement is called plate tectonics!
en.lesson4_text5: When plates move, pressure can build up and cause
en.lesson4_text5_and_6_speak: When plates move, pressure can build up and cause earthquakes
en.lesson4_text7: Tap and hold for a mega quake!
en.lesson4_text10: Our planet is constantly changing because of
en.lesson4_text9_and_10_speak: Our planet is constantly changing because of plate tectonics
en.lesson4_text11: Two continental plates that bump into each other can create mountains, hills and more!
en.lesson4_text12: A continental plate and an oceanic plate colliding can create volcanoes and trenches.
en.lesson4_text4_and_14_speak: Oceanic Plate: Makes up ocean floors
en.area2_instructions1: Please help me find eight different landforms before the prospector gets here and steals the data!
en.area2_instructions2: Drag the magnifying glass to find land forms
en.area2_instructions3: You did great! We beat the prospector. I can see him running away!
en.lesson3_text2: Fan shaped piece of land at the mouth of a river
en.lesson3_text1_and_2_speak: Delta : Fan shaped piece of land at the mouth of a river
en.lesson3_text6: Group of mountains connected by high land
en.lesson3_text5_and_6_speak: Mountain Range: Group of mountains connected by high land
en.lesson3_text8: Raised area of land not as high as a mountain
en.lesson3_text7_and_8_speak: Hill: Raised area of land not as high as a mountain
en.lesson3_text10: Broad, flat region along the ocean floor
en.lesson3_text9_and_10_speak: Ocean Basin: Broad, flat region along the ocean floor
en.lesson3_text12: Region along ocean floor where crust sinks
en.lesson3_text11_and_12_speak: Trench: Region along ocean floor where crust sinks
en.area3_tutorial1: They came out of nowhere and took my research on plate movements!
en.area3_tutorial2: You sure showed them! Thank you Super Study Buddies!
